questions.question: If you ................................. into James, tell him he owes me a drink.
questions.description: Should is sometimes used in the if-clause to suggest that something is very unlikely.

questions.question: Would it be all right if I ......................................... some friends tonight?
questions.description: We use the second conditional in more polite requests. In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: If I won this race, I would be delighted. Identify the conditional used in this sentence.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: Which conditional is used to talk about past situations that did not happen?
If my grandmother had been alive, she ........................................ 95 now.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If you .......................................... nicely, I would have helped you.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If I had gone to university, I .............................................. business.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: We ............................................ in trouble if she had recognized us.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If I ....................................... a little taller, I could be a model.
questions.description: In the second conditional we often use were instead of was.

questions.question: If we don't have a map, we .................................... be able to get out of here.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: Which conditional is used to talk about real and possible situations?
questions.description: We can use either  zero conditional or first conditional to talk about real situations.
